prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: X-ray AGNs in GOODSS at z=2.5-3.2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band-7 submillimeter observations of X-ray AGNs at z=2.5-3.2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The immediate objective of this proposal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z>1.5 AGNs to provide sensitive SFR constraints and construct detailed SFR distributions. Band 7 observations provide the best compromise between giving SFR constraints with minimal strong contamination from AGN activity (which we constrain using SED fitting) and high sensitivity to modest SFRs. We have six science goals, three for each of the two fields: GOODSS and COSMOS. The three science goals for each of the fields correspond to the three different sensitivity depths required to achieve our SFR limits (based on the evolution in the global SFR with redshift) at z=1.5-2.0, z=2.0-2.5, and z=2.5-3.2. On the basis of extensive SED fitting for the 132 X-ray AGNs in our sample, where we include fake ALMA photometry, to achieve our aims we require the following 1 sigma sensitivity limits at 870um: 0.09 mJy (z=1.5-2.0), 0.13 mJy (2.0-2.5), and 0.23 mJy (2.5-3.2). These sensitivity limits will be sufficient for us to measure SFRs down to 1/3 the stacked average found for X-ray AGNs over z=1.5-3.2. We do not require resolved imaging and therefore ~1 arcsec resolution is sufficient for our science goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: X-ray AGNs in COSMOS at z=1.5-2.0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 submillimeter observations of X-ray AGNs at z=1.5-2.0

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The immediate objective of this proposal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z>1.5 AGNs to provide sensitive SFR constraints and construct detailed SFR distributions. Band 7 observations provide the best compromise between giving SFR constraints with minimal strong contamination from AGN activity (which we constrain using SED fitting) and high sensitivity to modest SFRs. We have six science goals, three for each of the two fields: GOODSS and COSMOS. The three science goals for each of the fields correspond to the three different sensitivity depths required to achieve our SFR limits (based on the evolution in the global SFR with redshift) at z=1.5-2.0, z=2.0-2.5, and z=2.5-3.2. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the outstanding issues in the formation and evolution of galaxies is a definitive measurement of the impact that AGN have on Star Formation (SF). Observationally the picture is very mixed with conflicting results arguing for all scenarios: luminous AGNs suppressing, enhancing, or having no impact on SF! A major issue is the lack of sufficiently deep FIR-submm observations to directly measure the SF properties for the majority of the AGN population. The primary aim of this proposal is to build on our ALMA cycle 1 programme, combined with our carefully deblended Herschel photometry, to measure individual SFRs for a complete sample of X-ray selected AGN over the key X-ray luminosity and redshift ranges (L_X=10^43-10^45 erg/s and z=1.5-3.2), where the impact of AGNs on star formation is thought to be most prevalent. With the proposed observations we will construct detailed SFR distributions as a function of key AGN properties to accurately measure the impact that AGN have on SF in their host galaxies. Our observations will provide a key test for galaxy formation models which employ a wide variety of different prescriptions of AGN and SF activity.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00725.S: The First Accurate Measurements of the Growth Rates of Galaxies and Black Holes in a Distant Protocluster (PI: Alexander) 2012.1.00869.S: Star-formation rates for a complete sample of AGN hosts (PI: Mullaney)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Sheffield, University of
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Dartmouth College
